instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the authentication of edible animal blood food (EABF)?
Output: The spectrum used in the authentication of edible animal blood food (EABF) was the Fourier transform near-infrared (FT-NIR) spectrum.

Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the authentication of EABF using FT-NIR and chemometrics were the first derivative (1st Der), second derivative (2nd Der), centralization, standard normal variate transform (SNV), and multivariate scattering correction (MSC) paired with stepwise discriminant analysis (SWDA).

instruction: Can the FT-NIR coupled with fast chemometrics technique be considered a superior method for the authentication of edible animal blood food (EABF) compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the FT-NIR coupled with fast chemometrics technique can be considered a superior method for the authentication of edible animal blood food (EABF) compared to traditional methods. The study mentioned in the text demonstrates that this technique, when combined with Fisher linear discriminate analysis (Fisher LDA) and extreme learning machine (ELM), provides a higher accuracy of 93.89% in identifying adulterated EABF compared to traditional methods. Additionally, the optimized extreme learning machine regression (ELMR) models showed high correlation coefficients, low root mean square errors, and high residual prediction deviation and range error ratios, indicating the effectiveness of this technique in predicting adulteration levels. Overall, the results suggest that FT-NIR coupled with fast chemometrics has great potential in authenticating EABF and can be used to manage the EABF market, preventing illegal adulteration and unfair competition.
